title: Chapter 13 341 meeting
question: If I am represented by an attorney and the attorney of record does not show up, what happens?
answers:
Always be sure to choose an attorney whom you have confidence in. There are many attorneys out there, and you may be tempted to choose the one with the lowest attorney fee, but understand that that decision may have ramifications. Many times, an attorney can charge less because they have "volume" (a huge caseload, but that can lead to a less-personalized attention towards your case and, perhaps, a missed appointment. So, always do your homework on who you are hiring.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

If you are at the hearing and the attorney does not show up you should request a continuance so that you can obtain competent counsel. If it is after the fact you should send the attorney requesting a portion of your fee back, if they refuse then you can bring a motion for discouragement of a portion of his fees.

If this is a situation in the past tense, meaning the 341 has already occurred and your lawyer was not there, consider also asking the judge to have the attorney disgorge a portion of the fee you paid. The judges in my area are very, very protective of debtors who pay attorneys and the attorneys do not appear.

I will tell you that I once missed a 341, it was miscalendared. My clients proceeded anyway, and then called me when it was over. I apologize to them, and called the trustee and explained. As it turned out, there were no "weird" issues to be dealt with and so nothing was hurt by my not being there, other than embarrassment. My clients did not ask me to refund a portion of the fee, and I did not volunteer, for we had spent many, many hours making sure that the schedules and statements were properly drafted.

If you are concerned about a possible future problem, well, the response given by my colleagues holds true. You can ask that the 341 be continued, but if you would have to miss another few hours from work it may not be something you would want to do. The questions tend not to be too difficult, typically: 1) did you read the petition and schedules before you signed it; did you understand it; did you list all your debts and all your assets; what got you into bankruptcy are standard in my area, and then there may be 2) have you sued anyone, is anyone suing you, how long have you lived in California; do you have claims against anyone; and then 3) depending on what your schedules show.

If you have any, ANY reason to believe that your case is more than a "typical" case, or there are special areas of concern, then DO NOT go through the 341, get it continued, so that you can have your attorney present.

The attorney will show up. If they do not you will have the option to proceed without counsel. In the majority of cases it is Ok to do this as long as you told the truth and fully disclosed all property when you filed.

But wait for your attorney.

The court will send a show cause order to the attorney in most cases. The attorney can reprimanded if there is no good excuse, like a car accident.
